required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of a New Radiotracer (68Ga-NOTA-AE105) for Diagnosing Aggressive Cancer With Positron Emission Tomography
clinical_study.official_title: 68Ga-NOTA-AE105. Evaluation of a New Radiotracer Targeting uPAR (Urokinase Plasminogen Activator Receptor), for Positron Emission Tomography Imaging of the Invasive Cancer Phenotype. First in Human

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of the study is to test a new radiotracer called 68Ga-NOTA-AE105 for PET imaging of uPAR (urokinase plasminogen activator receptor). The tracer has the potential of identifying the invasive cancer phenotype, thereby distinguishing between aggressive and less aggressive tumors. This is a first in human study to test the radiotracer in cancer patients. The biodistribution and tumor uptake will be evaluated by repeated PET imaging (10 minutes, 1 hour and 2 hours post injection).

detailed_description.textblock: The primary objective of the study is to test a new radiotracer called 68Ga-NOTA-AE105 for PET imaging of uPAR (urokinase plasminogen activator receptor). The tracer has the potential of identifying the invasive cancer phenotype, thereby distinguishing between aggressive and less aggressive tumors. This is a first in human study to test the radiotracer in cancer patients. The biodistribution and tumor uptake will be evaluated by repeated PET scans (10 minutes, 1 and 2 hours post injection). The primary end points are safety, biodistribution and dosimetry of 68Ga-NOTA-AE105. In addition, the quantitative uptake of 68Ga-NOTA-AE105 will be compared to the expression of uPAR measured directly in tumor tissue obtained by surgery or biopsies. The project will be monitored and evaluated in accordance with the principles of Good Clinical Practice (GCP).

primary_outcome.description: The patients will be PET scanned 10 minutes, 1 hour and 2 hours post injection of the radiotracer 68Ga-NOTA-AE105. These timepoints will be used for assessment of biodistribution

The patients will be PET scanned 10 minutes, 1 hour and 2 hours post injection of the radiotracer 68Ga-NOTA-AE105. These timepoints will be used for calculation of dosimetry with the use of OLINDA/EXM software (mSv)
the patients will be monitored for safety (occurence of adverse events, vital signs, blood test parameters) following injection of the radiotracer 68Ga-NOTA-AE105

secondary_outcome.measure: Quantitative uptake of the radiotracer in tumor tissue
secondary_outcome.description: The patients will be PET scanned 10 minutes, 1 hour and 2 hours post injection of the radiotracer 68Ga-NOTA-AE105. These timepoints will be used for assessment of tumor uptake

arm_group.description: One injection of 68Ga-NOTA-AE105 (app. 200 MBq) followed by 3 PET/CT scans 10 minutes, 1 hour and 2 hours post injection

intervention.description: Following injection of 68Ga-NOTA-AE105 the patients will be PET scanned at 10 minutes, 1 hour and 2 hours post injection

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. diagnosed with cancer of prostate, breast or urinary bladder
2. capable of understanding and giving full informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
1. pregnancy
2. lactation
3. contraindication for the use of intravenous CT contrast-agencies
4. claustrophobia

facility.name: Department of Clinical Physiology, Nuclear Medicine and PET, Rigshospitalet

results_reference.citation: Persson M, Madsen J, Østergaard S, Jensen MM, Jørgensen JT, Juhl K, Lehmann C, Ploug M, Kjaer A. Quantitative PET of human urokinase-type plasminogen activator receptor with 64Cu-DOTA-AE105: implications for visualizing cancer invasion. J Nucl Med. 2012 Jan;53(1):138-45. doi: 10.2967/jnumed.110.083386.
